title: Multi-focus - difference in cat plaque 2 boxplots

content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.Dental disease in domestic cats is commonly associated with the accumulation of plaque on the teeth. A cat food manufacturer is studying the accumulation of plaque on the teeth of cats from a certain population. The accumulation of plaque is assessed using a fluorescent light technique (<math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where an evaluator reviews images of the cat’s teeth and assigns an overall rating from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with lower values indicating less plaque. A previous study indicates the population distribution of the <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings for the teeth of cats is bimodal with mean <math alttext="mu equals 59" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>59</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Compare the shapes of the sampling distributions of the sample mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating for random samples of <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats and for random samples of <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats from the population. Explain your answer.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.Dental disease in domestic cats is commonly associated with the accumulation of plaque on the teeth. A cat food manufacturer is studying the accumulation of plaque on the teeth of cats from a certain population. The accumulation of plaque is assessed using a fluorescent light technique (<math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), where an evaluator reviews images of the cat’s teeth and assigns an overall rating from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with lower values indicating less plaque. A previous study indicates the population distribution of the <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings for the teeth of cats is bimodal with mean <math alttext="mu equals 59" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>59</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.(a) Compare the shapes of the sampling distributions of the sample mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating for random samples of <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats and for random samples of <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats from the population. Explain your answer.

(b) Which of the following would be more likely to obtain from the population?• A random sample of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats having a mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating that is less than <math alttext="54" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>54</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>or• A random sample of <math alttext="400" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats having a mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating that is less than <math alttext="54" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>54</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>Justify your answer.

The manufacturer conducted a study to investigate whether a new dental treat is different in minimizing the accumulation of plaque on the teeth of cats than the existing dental treat. The manufacturer randomly assigned <math alttext="70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cats from a cat sanctuary to receive one of the two dental treats, with <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving the new dental treat and <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving the existing dental treat. At the end of the study, an evaluator, who was not aware of each cat’s assigned dental treat, determined the <math alttext="F L T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating for each cat. The two boxplots shown display the results of the study. (c) Based on the boxplots, write a few sentences comparing the distributions of the <math alttext="F L T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings for the cats who received the new dental treat and the cats who received the existing dental treat.

The manufacturer will conduct a hypothesis test to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that the mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> rating is different for cats receiving the new dental treat rather than the existing dental treat.(d) Name the appropriate hypothesis test and state, in words, the hypotheses.

Assume the conditions for inference have been met. A <math alttext="96" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>96</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the difference in the mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (new dental treat minus existing) was calculated to be <math alttext="negative 1.286 plus or minus 8.984" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1.286</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>8.984</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based only on this confidence interval, is the difference in the mean <math alttext="F L T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ratings statistically significant? Justify your answer.
(f) Can the findings of this study be generalized to all cats? Explain why or why not.

topic.text: 1.9: Comparing Distributions of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
